problems.title: Cut the Array
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array of nn non-negative integers [a1,a2,…,an][a1,a2,…,an].

Your task is to cut it into three non-empty parts: a prefix, a middle part, and a suffix. Formally, you need to choose two integers ll and rr such that 1≤l<r<n1≤l<r<n, and obtain three parts:

Let s1,s2,s3s1,s2,s3 be the remainders of the sums of these parts modulo 33. In other words:

Your task is to find such boundaries ll and rr that either all numbers s1,s2,s3s1,s2,s3 are different, or all numbers s1,s2,s3s1,s2,s3 are the same.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of two lines:

  • the first line contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤403≤n≤40);
  • the second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤400≤ai≤40).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, if a suitable pair of integers ll and rr (1≤l<r<n1≤l<r<n) exists, output these two integers (if there are multiple suitable pairs, you can output any of them). Otherwise, output two integers equal to 00.
problems.noteHtml:
Consider the examples from the statement:

  • in the first example, the array is cut into parts [1,2,3][1,2,3], [4,5][4,5], [6][6]; s1=s2=s3=0s1=s2=s3=0;
  • in the second example, there is no suitable cut;
  • in the third example, the array is cut into parts [2][2], [1][1], [0][0]; s1=2s1=2, s2=1s2=1, s3=0s3=0;
  • in the fourth example, the array is cut into parts [7,2][7,2], [6,2][6,2], [4][4]; s1=0s1=0, s2=2s2=2, s3=1s3=1.

problems.title: Maximum Cost Permutation
problems.statementHtml:
Recall that a permutation of length nn is a sequence of length nn such that each integer from 11 to nn appears in it exactly once.

Let's define the cost of a permutation as the minimum length of its contiguous subsegment (possibly empty) that needs to be sorted so that the entire permutation becomes sorted in ascending order.

You are given an integer array pp consisting of integers from 00 to nn, where no positive (strictly greater than zero) integer appears more than once. You should replace zeros with integers so that the array pp becomes a permutation.

Your task is to calculate the maximum possible cost of the resulting permutation.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (0≤pi≤n0≤pi≤n). No positive integer appears more than once in this sequence.

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the maximum possible cost of the resulting permutation.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, you can make a permutation [1,3,4,2,5][1,3,4,2,5] with the cost 33, because you have to sort segment [2,4][2,4].

In the second example, you can make a permutation [2,3,1][2,3,1] with the cost 33, because you have to sort segment [1,3][1,3].

In the third example, there is only one possible permutation — [1,2,3,4][1,2,3,4], with the cost 00, because the permutation is already sorted.

In the fourth example, there is only one possible permutation — [1,3,2][1,3,2], with the cost 22, because you have to sort segment [2,3][2,3].

problems.title: Non-Descending Arrays
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two integer arrays aa and bb both of length nn.

You can choose any subset of indices and swap the elements at those positions (i. e. make a swap(aiai, bibi) for each ii in the subset). A subset of indices is considered good if, after the swapping, both arrays are sorted in non-descending order.

Your task is to calculate the number of good subsets. Since the answer can be large, print it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤5001≤t≤500) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10001≤ai≤1000).

The third line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤10001≤bi≤1000).

Additional constraint on the input: there is at least one good subset.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the number of good subsets, taken modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, there are 22 good subsets: {1, 3} and {2}.

In the second example, there are 22 good subsets: {1} and {}.

In the third example, there are 88 good subsets: {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}, {1, 2, 3}, {1, 2, 4, 5}, {1, 2}, {3, 4, 5}, {3}, {4, 5} and {}.

problems.title: Price Tags
problems.statementHtml:
Imagine that you are the owner of a store. Before the start of a new season, you decided to clear your store of leftover goods, and therefore you decided to hold a total sale.

You have nn different items in your store: the ii-th item costs cici coins. Each item has a price tag with the corresponding price cici. You decided to hold a sale in the format: "we divided all the prices xx times." Formally, this means that you choose a common coefficient xx, and during the sale, the ii-th item will cost ⌈cix⌉⌈cix⌉ coins (where ⌈y⌉⌈y⌉ denotes rounding up).

To avoid confusion among the customers, you need to pin new price tags with new prices on all items, but printing new price tags is costly. Specifically, each printed price tag will cost you yy coins.

Therefore, you had a brilliant idea — why not use the existing price tags and simply repin them on other items? So, you'll need to print price tags only for those items that do not have a corresponding price tag available.

There remains one last question: by how much should you reduce the prices, or what xx should you choose? The coefficient xx must be an integer strictly greater than 11 and such that the total income is maximized. The total income is equal to the total value of the items minus the cost of the printed price tags.

Determine the maximum possible total income.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤101≤t≤10) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and yy (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105; 1≤y≤1091≤y≤109) — the number of items and the cost of printing one price tag.

The second line contains nn integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn (1≤ci≤2⋅1051≤ci≤2⋅105) — the initial prices of the items.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the maximum total income.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, it is optimal to choose x=3x=3. The new prices of the items will be [17,50,17,50,50][17,50,17,50,50]. In this case, we can use two old price tags of 5050, and we will have to print three price tags for 1717, 1717, and 5050. As a result, the income will be 17+50+17+50+50−51⋅3=3117+50+17+50+50−51⋅3=31.

In the second test case, it is optimal to choose x=2x=2. The new prices will be [21,21,21][21,21,21], and we will have to print 33 new price tags.

In the third test case, it is optimal to choose x=111x=111.

In the fourth test case, it is optimal to choose x=2x=2. The new prices will be the same as the old ones, so no new price tags will be printed.

problems.title: Looking at Towers (easy version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The only differences between the easy and the difficult version are the constraints on tt and nn.

Consider a row of mm towers; the height of the ii-th tower in the row is hihi.

If you look at this row of towers from the left, you see all towers that are strictly higher than all towers before them. Similarly, if you look at this row of towers from the right, you see all towers that are strictly higher than all towers after them. For example, if the towers have heights [3,5,5,7,4,6,7,2,4][3,5,5,7,4,6,7,2,4], then:

Let L(h)L(h) be the set of heights you see from the left, and R(h)R(h) be the set of heights you see from the right when the sequence of heights is hh. In the example above, L(h)={3,5,7}L(h)={3,5,7}, and R(h)={4,7}R(h)={4,7}.

You are given a sequence a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. Your task is to calculate the number of subsequences of aa such that L(a)=L(a′)L(a)=L(a′) and R(a)=R(a′)R(a)=R(a′), where a′a′ is the subsequence you consider. Two subsequences are different if indices of chosen elements are different.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of two lines:

  • the first line contains one integer nn (1≤n≤50001≤n≤5000);
  • the second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109).

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 50005000.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print one integer — the number of subsequences a′a′ of the given sequence aa such that L(a)=L(a′)L(a)=L(a′) and R(a)=R(a′)R(a)=R(a′). Since it might be huge, print it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, L(a)={4,8}L(a)={4,8}, R(a)={3,8}R(a)={3,8}. The subsequences included in the answer are:

  • [4,8,3][4,8,3] (the 11-st, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,8,3][4,8,3] (the 33-rd, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,2,8,3][4,2,8,3] (the 11-st, the 22-nd, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,4,8,3][4,4,8,3] (the 11-st, the 33-rd, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,2,4,8,3][4,2,4,8,3] (the whole sequence).

In the second example, the only valid subsequence is the given sequence itself.

problems.title: Looking at Towers (difficult version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the difficult version of the problem. The only differences between the easy and the difficult version are the constraints on tt and nn.

Consider a row of mm towers; the height of the ii-th tower in the row is hihi.

If you look at this row of towers from the left, you see all towers that are strictly higher than all towers before them. Similarly, if you look at this row of towers from the right, you see all towers that are strictly higher than all towers after them. For example, if the towers have heights [3,5,5,7,4,6,7,2,4][3,5,5,7,4,6,7,2,4], then:

Let L(h)L(h) be the set of heights you see from the left, and R(h)R(h) be the set of heights you see from the right when the sequence of heights is hh. In the example above, L(h)={3,5,7}L(h)={3,5,7}, and R(h)={4,7}R(h)={4,7}.

You are given a sequence a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. Your task is to calculate the number of subsequences of aa such that L(a)=L(a′)L(a)=L(a′) and R(a)=R(a′)R(a)=R(a′), where a′a′ is the subsequence you consider. Two subsequences are different if indices of chosen elements are different.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of two lines:

  • the first line contains one integer nn (1≤n≤3⋅1051≤n≤3⋅105);
  • the second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109).

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print one integer — the number of subsequences a′a′ of the given sequence aa such that L(a)=L(a′)L(a)=L(a′) and R(a)=R(a′)R(a)=R(a′). Since it might be huge, print it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, L(a)={4,8}L(a)={4,8}, R(a)={3,8}R(a)={3,8}. The subsequences included in the answer are:

  • [4,8,3][4,8,3] (the 11-st, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,8,3][4,8,3] (the 33-rd, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,2,8,3][4,2,8,3] (the 11-st, the 22-nd, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,4,8,3][4,4,8,3] (the 11-st, the 33-rd, the 44-th and the 55-th element);
  • [4,2,4,8,3][4,2,4,8,3] (the whole sequence).

In the second example, the only valid subsequence is the given sequence itself.

problems.title: Bracket Groups
problems.statementHtml:
A regular bracket sequence is a bracket sequence that can be transformed into a correct arithmetic sequence. For example:

You are given nn bracket sequences s1,s2,…,sns1,s2,…,sn (not necessarily regular) and an even integer kk. Your task is to split all of them into groups in such a way that:

What is the smallest number of groups that this can be achieved for? If it's impossible to do for any number of groups, report so. Otherwise, print the groups and any valid regular bracket sequence for each group. If there are multiple answers with the smallest number of groups, print any of them.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤501≤n≤50; 2≤k≤502≤k≤50; kk is even).

The ii-th of the next nn lines contains a bracket sequence sisi (2≤|si|≤k2≤|si|≤k). It consists only of characters '(' and ')'.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
If it's impossible to split all bracket sequences into groups according to the rules, then print −1−1.

Otherwise, print the smallest possible number of groups mm in the first line. Then, mm blocks of data should follow:

  • The first line of each block should contain a regular bracket sequence of length kk.
  • The second line should contain a single integer gg — the number of bracket sequences in the current group.
  • The third line should contain gg integers from 11 to nn — the indices of the bracket sequences that belong to the current group.

None of these bracket sequences should be a substring of the chosen regular bracket sequence. Each index from 11 to nn should belong to exactly one group.

If there are multiple answers with the smallest mm, print any of them.

tutorial.contentHtml:
2144A - Cut the Array

Idea: BledDest

Tutorial

2144A - Cut the Array

Of course, we can iterate through the positions l and r, and then check if we get a valid cut. However, there is a simpler solution.

Let's try to rephrase the condition "either all numbers s1,s2,s3 are different, or all numbers s1,s2,s3 are the same". Since these are remainders when divided by 3, their sum will be equal to 0 modulo 3:

  • if they are all equal to 0, 1, or 2, then their sum is divisible by 3;
  • otherwise, one of them is 0, another is 1, and the third is 2, and their sum equals 3.

On the other hand, if s1+s2+s3 is equal to 0 modulo 3, then there are two possible cases:

  • either s1=s2, in which case s3 will be equal to them (otherwise their sum would not be divisible by 3);
  • or s1≠s2, then s3=3−s1−s2, and regardless of the values of s1 and s2, s3 will differ from them.

Thus, if the sum of the array is not divisible by 3, then there is no suitable cut; and if it is divisible by 3, then any cut will be valid.
